title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
In this workshop, you will practice using git bisect to identify the commit that introduced a bug into a repository. You will also make a pull request to fix the bug once you‚Äôve found it.



Before beginning, make sure you have: - Forked the repository git-bisect-demo into your own GitHub account. - Cloned the repository from your fork to your local machine.





Go to the git-bisect-demo repository.
In the top-right corner, click the Fork button to create your own copy of the repository on GitHub.
After forking, clone your fork to your local machine using the following command:
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/git-bisect-demo.git
Navigate to the cloned repository:
cd git-bisect-demo






The git-bisect-demo repository contains a bug in the square() function. Your task is to identify the commit that introduced the bug using git bisect.
Begin by starting the git bisect process:
git bisect start
Mark the current (bad) commit:
Since the latest commit has the bug in it (the square() function is broken), we will mark it as bad:
git bisect bad
Identify a good commit:
The square() function was working correctly before the bug was introduced. To identify a ‚Äúgood‚Äù commit, we need to mark a commit before the bug was introduced. You can look at the GitHub history or use git log to find a commit before the bug was introduced (for example, commit 10).
git bisect good <commit-hash>

Replace <commit-hash> with the hash of a known good commit (such as the initial commit or the last commit before the bug was introduced).







Now, Git will automatically check out a commit halfway between the good and bad commits. Your job is to test whether the bug is present in this commit.

Open the script.R file and inspect the code. If the bug is present, mark the commit as bad:
git bisect bad
If the bug is not present, mark the commit as good:
git bisect good

Git will continue to narrow down the commits by checking out commits halfway between the last good and bad marks. Repeat the process of inspecting the code and marking each commit as either good or bad until Git identifies the commit that introduced the bug.






Once the commit has been identified, you should make a branch from that point to fix the bug.
git switch -C fix-square-bug
Open the script.R file and modify the square() function to correct the bug:
square <- function(x) {
  return(x * x)  # Fix the bug (it was previously x + x)
}
Commit the fix:
git add script.R
git commit -m "Fix bug in square function"
Push the changes to GitHub:

git push origin fix-square-bug





End the git bisect session:
git bisect reset
Push your changes to your GitHub fork:
git push origin master
Go to your GitHub repository and create a Pull Request from your fork‚Äôs master branch to the original repository (mikelydeamore/git-bisect-demo).

Make sure to provide a detailed description in the pull request, explaining:

The bug that was fixed.
The process you used to find the bug using git bisect.
The fix you made.








If you‚Äôre not sure which commit is good or bad, use git log to help you identify the commit hashes.
If you make a mistake or want to change your good/bad marks, use git bisect reset to start the process over.
Don‚Äôt forget to push your changes to your fork after fixing the bug!





In this workshop, you learned how to use git bisect to find the commit that introduced a bug in a Git repository. You also learned how to fix the bug and create a pull request with your fix. This process is very useful for debugging and narrowing down the source of issues in large codebases.



In this exercise, you‚Äôll write a test script that automatically checks for the bug in the square function, which you can use during the git bisect process. This script will be used to help you determine the exact commit that introduced the bug.



Understand the Bug

The bug is that the square function produces incorrect results for certain inputs, and you‚Äôll need to test it during the git bisect process.

Create a Test Script for Bisect

Create a new file called test-bisect.R in the repository. This file will contain an R script for testing the bug. It will return 0 (success) if the bug is not present and 1 (failure) if the bug is present. git bisect uses this exit code to determine whether to continue searching in the good or bad commit range.

Write the Bisect Test Script

The script should check the functionality of the square function. For the purposes of this exercise, assume the bug is present when the result of square(2) is not equal to 4.


source("script.R")
result <- square(2)

if (result != 4) {
    quit(status = 1)
} else {
    quit(status = 0)
}




This script runs an R command using Rscript, sources the script.R file, calls the square function with an input of 2, and checks if the result is 4.
If the result is not 4, the script exits with a status code of 1, which signals git bisect that the bug is present in the current commit (bad commit).
If the result is 4, the script exits with a status code of 0, signaling that the commit is ‚Äúgood‚Äù.


Run git bisect

Now, you can start git bisect using the following commands:


# Start the bisect process by specifying a good commit and a bad commit
git bisect start
git bisect bad # This marks the current commit as bad (contains the bug)
git bisect good <commit-hash> # This marks an older commit as good (before the bug)

# Use the bisect_test.sh script to automatically test each commit
git bisect run Rscript test-bisect.R

Interpreting the Results

git bisect will automatically check each commit in the range between the good and bad commits by using the bisect_test.sh script. When the process finishes, git bisect will tell you the first bad commit where the bug was introduced.
Once the bisect process completes, run the following command to reset the repository to its original state:


git bisect reset

Check whether the automatic bisect has worked

Check the contents of script.R and see if you have found the bug. If not, you may need to modify test-bisect.R to better capture the case where the bug is present!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Understand: - Why Git can‚Äôt handle big files normally - How to recover if you accidentally try to commit something too big - The basics of Git LFS





Create a new GitHub repository:
git-lfs-practice
Clone it to your computer using RStudio:

File ‚Üí New Project ‚Üí Version Control ‚Üí Git
Paste the repo URL






1l. Download the zip file from the Week 8 Moodle website





Stage bigfile.txt
Try to commit it.

üîµ Expected Result:
GitHub will likely reject the push (file too large >100MB), or your Git client will warn you.
‚úÖ You‚Äôve hit a real size limit!





Try to revert the bad commit:
git revert HEAD

üîµ Expected Result:
Git won‚Äôt let you ‚Äî because the giant file is still in the commit history.
‚ö†Ô∏è Key point: git revert adds new commits; it doesn‚Äôt erase old ones.





Do a soft reset to move back before the bad commit:
git reset --soft HEAD~1
Now unstage the big file manually in RStudio (or):
git restore --staged bigfile.txt
Delete bigfile.txt from your project folder.
Commit the new clean state:
"Remove large file after reset"






Install Git LFS:
Follow instructions here ‚Üí https://git-lfs.github.com/
Track large files safely:
git lfs install
git lfs track "*.csv"
Then commit/push files as usual ‚Äî Git LFS manages the storage.








Problem
Solution




Committed a huge file
git reset + delete manually


Need to work with big files safely
Use Git LFS



üéâ You survived a Git crisis ‚Äî just like real developers do!

Many templates are available:
Journal articles Monash templates Question/Answer templates

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
The bibliography file
First thing we need is a place to store information about our references.
A standard file format is called the bibliography database file (which ends in .bib).

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
The bibliography file

To cite a paper in the text, we use the key from the bib file
These files are plain text, so you can open them in RStudio or VSCode


To get bib entries:

Google Scholar
Reference manager such as Zotero or Mendeley

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
The bibliography file: Example
@Manual{R-base,
  title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical
           Computing}, 
  author = {{R Core Team}},
  organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing},
  address = {Vienna, Austria},
  year = {2019},
  url = {https://www.R-project.org},
}

To cite this in your quarto file, use @R-base

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Citing R packages
You can get the citations for R packages using toBibtex(citation("tidyverse"))

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Large files in git and GitHub
text:
Large files in git and GitHub
What happens when you commit a big file on GitHub?
Files larger than 50mb won‚Äôt upload properly

Instead, we deal with these using Git Large File Storage (lfs).
Please see info for installation here and make sure you install this extension.


GitHub and BitBucket both have LFS support, and handle changes to these files much more sensibly.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Setup for git LFS
To set up large file storage:

Navigate to the repo
In the CLI, type git lfs install

Now, large files can be tracked using the relevant command. For example:
git lfs track '*.nc'
git lfs track '*.csv'
git lfs track '*.pdf'
Note the quotes!

This will create a .gitattributes file. Make sure to add this to your repo.
Then, use your standard workflow of add, commit, push.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Summary

Navigate to the local repo and run git lfs install
`git lfs track ‚Äú*.csv‚Äù
git add .gitattributes
git add data.csv as per normal


It is essential you run git lfs install before committing and pushing, otherwise you will get an error message.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: What if I already have a large file?
text:
What if I already have a large file?
If you have committed a large file, you probably got an error message you have to fix.
Recall:
git reset --soft HEAD~1
Then:
git lfs install
git add .gitattributes file.csv
git commit -m "Adding data files through GIT LFS"
git push origin main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
More on committing
So far, we‚Äôve used a one-line commit (although we could do with more practice on those)

We can add more text into a commit, and many times this is sensible.
Detailed commit structure:
First line
Blank line
Rest of the text

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git tags
tags are custom labels or references that point to specific points in your git history
Generlaly used to capture a specific point in the repo history, like a release, or a report milestone.






Tip


You can think of a tag like a branch that doesn‚Äôt change



Unlike branches, tags don‚Äôt have any further history of commits.
Great tutorial on tags here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Git tags example

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Types of tags
There are two types of tags: lightweight and annotated. The difference is the metadata they come with.
Best practice is lightweight tags for personal use, and annotated tags as marks for version releases
Annotated tags stores extra metadata like the tagger name, email and date
Lightweight tags are only a pointer to a commit.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Creating and sharing tags
To create an annotated tag:
git tag -a v 1.0
or
git tag -a v1.0 SHA1
This will create a new annotated tag with label v1.0. The command will open your text editor for further metadata.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Annotated tag example

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Lightweight tags
git tag v1.0 will create a lightweight tag

Can you spot the difference?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Listing tags
git tag

git tag -n will also show us the associated message, or you can do git show tagname

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Tagging old commits
By default, git tag creates a tag on HEAD
If you want to tag an old commit:
git log --oneline
git tag -a v1.2 15027957951b64cf874c3557a0f

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Sharing tags
Sharing tags is similar to pushing branches.
By default, git push does not push tags
git push origin tagname will push the tag.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Viewing your tags on GitHub

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Viewing your tags on GitHub

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Checking tags
You can check out tags: git checkout v1.0
This will put you in a detached HEAD state, so commits won‚Äôt be recorded

Unless??

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Deleting a tag

git tag: Lists tags
git tag -d v1: Deletes tag v1
git push origin --delete v1: Deletes it from the remote

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Why use tags?
We could just use a branch (that never gets merged) instead of a tag.
For storing points in history, this is fine (although not the intention of a branch)
A branch is supposed to be a ‚Äúvariation‚Äù on the main repository, not a point-in-time record
Tags are designed to fill that void.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Learn how to remove files from Git tracking with git rm, and prevent them from being re-added with a .gitignore file.







Create a new repository:
git-ignore-cleanup
‚úÖ Check ‚ÄúAdd a README file‚Äù






Go to File ‚Üí New Project ‚Üí Version Control ‚Üí Git
Paste the repo URL (SSH or HTTPS)
Choose a location and click Create Project

‚úÖ You‚Äôre now working in a Git-tracked project.






Create a new qmd in RStudio:

Go to File ‚Üí New File ‚Üí Quarto Document

Save the file as notes.qmd
Add some content like:
summary(mtcars)
Stage and commit the file:
"Add analysis script"






Download the data from Week 2 on Moodle, and save it into your project as data.csv
Stage and commit:
git add data.csv
git commit -m "Add raw data"





Realise you don‚Äôt want this in version control, but you still need it for local use.
In the terminal:
git rm --cached data.csv
git commit -m "Stop tracking data.csv"
‚úÖ data.csv is still on your computer, but Git will no longer track it.




To prevent it from being accidentally added again:

Open (or create) a .gitignore file in your repo root
Add:
data.csv
Save and stage the .gitignore file
Commit:
"Ignore data.csv"






Run:

git status
‚úÖ You should not see data.csv listed anywhere ‚Äî Git is now ignoring it.




Let‚Äôs now try squashing a few commits into one clean one.




Edit your .qmd file and make 3 separate commits:

Add a new section or chunk ‚Üí commit: "Add section"
Fix a typo ‚Üí commit: "Fix typo"
Add a final comment ‚Üí commit: "Add footnote"


‚úÖ Commit after each change using the Git pane or terminal.




Run in the Terminal:
git log --oneline
You should see something like:
c3d4e5f Add footnote
b2c3d4e Fix typo
a1b2c3d Add section
...




git rebase -i HEAD~3
You‚Äôll see:
pick a1b2c3d Add section
pick b2c3d4e Fix typo
pick c3d4e5f Add footnote




Change it to:
pick a1b2c3d Add section
squash b2c3d4e
squash c3d4e5f
Save and write a new combined commit message like:
Add section with typo fix and footnote
Save again to finish the rebase.




Run:
git log --oneline
‚úÖ You should now see one clean commit where there were three.






Why is --amend useful when working on a single file?
When is it good practice to squash commits?
What would happen if you did this after pushing?








Action
Command




Fix your last commit
git commit --amend


Combine multiple commits
git rebase -i HEAD~N


Keep your history clean
Use these before pushing



üéâ You‚Äôve just learned to write cleaner, more professional commit histories!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
ETC5513: Reproducible and Collaborative Practices
Undoing, exporing and cleaning with git
Lecturer: Michael Lydeamore
Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics




michael.lydeamore@monash.edu


 Week 7


rcp.numbat.space

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Open Frame

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Fixing your commit messages
Last week most of us got stuck in Vi mode
To fix this, run the following:
Windows
git config --global core.editor notepad
MacOS
git config --global core.editor "open -e -W -n"
This will set either notepad or TextEdit to be your commit editor (much nicer).
On Mac, note you must quit (not just close the window) for the commit message to be complete.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† Today‚Äôs Goals

Learn how to safely undo and explore commits
Understand how to recover lost work
Get more comfortable with the Git timeline and history
Clean up messy projects

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† Git Mental Model
Git works across three layers:

Working Directory: your actual files
Index (Staging Area): what will be in your next commit
HEAD (Repository): your last committed snapshot

Some examples: - git add moves changes ‚Üí index - git commit moves index ‚Üí HEAD - git reset moves HEAD pointer (soft/mixed/hard)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üîÅ Reverting and Resetting ‚Äì Recap
git revert

Creates a new commit that undoes a previous one
Safe on shared branches (e.g.¬†main)

git revert <commit-hash>

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üßµ Detached HEAD

Happens when you check out a specific commit, not a branch
Useful for exploring history
If you make changes in this state, they can be lost unless you make a branch

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Demo: Detached HEAD + Branch

In the terminal or Git pane:

git log --oneline

Copy a commit hash from earlier and run:

git checkout <commit-hash>
You‚Äôre now in detached HEAD!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚úçÔ∏è git commit --amend
Use this when you:

Made a typo in the last commit message
Forgot to include a file
Want to slightly edit the last commit

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Demo: Amending a Commit

Make a small commit

Realize you forgot something

Stage the missing file, then run:

git commit --amend
üéØ You can edit the message or leave it the same
‚ö†Ô∏è Avoid --amend if you‚Äôve already pushed the commit

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üîç git reflog

Shows every move of HEAD (including things Git log forgets)
Useful to recover commits after a reset or checkout

git reflog

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: üóëÔ∏è git rm: Remove Files from the Repository
text:
üóëÔ∏è git rm: Remove Files from the Repository

Use git rm to delete a tracked file from both your working directory and Git‚Äôs index.
Git will stage the deletion automatically.

git rm filename.txt
git commit -m "Remove filename.txt"
‚úÖ After this commit, the file will no longer exist in your working directory or the repository.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: ‚ùó Why Not Just Delete the File?
text:
‚ùó Why Not Just Delete the File?

If you delete a file in RStudio or your file browser:

Git will show it as ‚Äúdeleted: filename.txt‚Äù
But you still need to git add the deletion


# After deleting manually:
git status         # Shows deletion
git add filename.txt
git commit -m "Remove file"
‚úÖ git rm does both steps at once ‚Äî it‚Äôs safer and cleaner

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üí° Recovering a Deleted File
If you haven‚Äôt committed the deletion yet:
git restore filename.txt
If you already committed the deletion:
git checkout HEAD~1 -- filename.txt
‚úÖ Or use git reflog to find the commit where the file still existed

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: üßæ git rm --cached: Keep the File, Remove It from Git
text:
üßæ git rm --cached: Keep the File, Remove It from Git

Use this when you‚Äôve added a file to Git by mistake, but you don‚Äôt want to delete it from your computer
Git stops tracking it ‚Äî but the file stays in your working directory

git rm --cached data.csv
git commit -m "Stop tracking data.csv"
‚úÖ The file will still be on disk, but not in the next commit

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† Common Use Case

You committed a large data file by accident


Add the filename to .gitignore
Run:

git rm --cached data.csv
git commit -m "Remove data.csv from tracking"

Push your changes

The file is now ignored and won‚Äôt be re-added

‚úÖ Useful for cleaning up mistakes without losing the file

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üßπ git clean

Deletes untracked files (not in Git yet)
Helpful when switching branches or cleaning clutter

git clean -n   # dry run
git clean -f   # permanently delete

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Warning

git clean is permanent
You can‚Äôt undo it with reflog or reset
Always use -n first to preview

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Activity: Cleaning Up

In RStudio, create a few new files but don‚Äôt add them to Git
Run:

git status
git clean -n

If it looks right:

git clean -f
‚úÖ Now those untracked files are gone!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† When to Use What



Situation
Use This




Undo safely on shared branches
git revert


Clean up your last commit
git commit --amend


Rewind local commit history
git reset


Accidentally reset or lost work
git reflog


Delete untracked junk
git clean

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Questions?

When would you not use reset?
What does reflog help you find that log doesn‚Äôt?
Have you ever thought you lost work but actually didn‚Äôt?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üç• What Is Squashing?
Squashing means combining multiple commits into a single one.
It‚Äôs useful for:

Cleaning up messy history
Preparing code before pushing or merging
Grouping small fixes into one meaningful commit


Squashing doesn‚Äôt change your code ‚Äî just your history!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† How Squash Works
Before squashing:
A -- B -- C -- D  (main)
         ‚Üë
       Fix typo
If B, C, and D are all part of one logical change, we can squash:
A -- [B+C+D]  (main)
‚úÖ One clean commit ‚Äî easier to read, review, and share.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üõ†Ô∏è How to Squash Commits
Use interactive rebase to squash:
git rebase -i HEAD~3
You‚Äôll see:
pick abc123 Add feature
pick def456 Fix typo
pick ghi789 Update docs
Change to:
pick abc123 Add feature
squash def456
squash ghi789
Then save + edit the commit message.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è When (and When Not) to Squash
‚úÖ Good times to squash:

Before pushing a feature branch
To combine tiny commits (‚Äúfix typo‚Äù, ‚Äúrename var‚Äù, ‚Äúoops‚Äù)

‚ùå Avoid squashing:

After you‚Äôve pushed to a shared branch (rewrites history!)

1\begin{document}

Open the document

Sections each get a ‚Äòsection‚Äô header

We are going to use LaTeX via Quarto files
In order to be able to use LaTeX within our Quarto documents, we need to install tinytex:
quarto install tinytex
or
quarto install tinytex --update-path
You don‚Äôt need the full LaTex installation for this unit, just this package.


More info about tinytex here

LaTeX in 24 Hours A Practical Guide for Scientific Writing

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Quarto PDF themes
Another way to include styling is to use a Quarto PDF extension. For example:

Quarto Monash
Quarto Letter
Fancy Header

‚Ä¶and more here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Quarto PDF themes
These themes have the advantage of having done a lot of the LateX formatting for you. Looking inside the Quarto Monash memo, we have:
\pretitle{%
$if(branding)$%
\begin{textblock}{4}(1.9,0.85)\includegraphics[height=1.5cm]{monash2}\end{textblock}%
\begin{textblock}{4}(17.25,0.8)\includegraphics[height=1.5cm]{MBSPortrait}\end{textblock}%
\begin{textblock}{6}(13,28)\includegraphics[height=0.7cm]{AACSB}~~~
        \includegraphics[height=0.7cm]{EQUIS}~~~
        \includegraphics[height=0.7cm]{AMBA}
\end{textblock}
Which is doing a lot of positioning of pictures for the template.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
In this workshop, you‚Äôll practice collaborative editing using branches, rebasing, and pull requests in a Quarto project.
You‚Äôll simulate a real-world collaboration scenario: - One student makes changes to the main branch - Another student works on a feature branch - Before contributing, the second student rebases to keep history clean



Assign roles:

Student A = Repository owner

Student B = Contributor

You‚Äôll swap roles after completing the exercise.





Create a new GitHub repo named something like quarto-rebase-demo

‚úÖ Add a README file

Clone it locally:

git clone git@github.com:your-username/quarto-rebase-demo.git
cd quarto-rebase-demo

Create a Quarto file called collab.qmd:

---
title: "Rebase Demo"
format: html
---

# Introduction

This is a collaborative Quarto project.

# Contributions

<!-- Student sections will go here -->

Commit and push:

git add collab.qmd
git commit -m "Add initial Quarto file"
git push origin main

Share the GitHub link with Student B.

‚úÖ Student B can now fork the project.





Fork Student A‚Äôs repository on GitHub

Clone your fork:

git clone git@github.com:your-username/quarto-rebase-demo.git
cd quarto-rebase-demo

Create a new branch for your work:

git branch my-section
git switch my-section

Open collab.qmd and add your section under ‚Äú# Contributions‚Äù:

# Jamie‚Äôs Section

This is my contribution to the Quarto project.

Save the file, then stage and commit:

git add collab.qmd
git commit -m "Add Jamie‚Äôs section"
‚úÖ Don‚Äôt push yet ‚Äî Student A will now make another change.




While Student B is working, Student A adds a new section to collab.qmd:
# Instructor's Section

This section was added after Student B began work.

Save the file, then commit and push:

git add collab.qmd
git commit -m "Add instructor‚Äôs section"
git push origin main
‚úÖ Now Student B‚Äôs branch is behind main.





Check your remotes:

git remote -v
You should only see one remote called origin

Add Student A‚Äôs repo as a remote:

git remote add upstream git@github.com:student-a-username/quarto-rebase-demo.git
git fetch upstream

Check your remotes and branches again:

git remote -v
git branch -v

Rebase your branch:

git merge upstream/main

If there are any conflicts, Git will pause and show them in collab.qmd. Edit the file and resolve them manually. It might look like this:

<<<<<<< HEAD
# Jamie‚Äôs Section
This is my contribution to the Quarto project.
=======
# Instructor's Section
This section was added after Student B began work.
>>>>>>> upstream/main

After fixing the file, run:

git add collab.qmd
git commit -m "Merge conflict in upstream"

Once merging is complete, push your changes to your fork:

git push origin main





Go to your fork on GitHub

Click ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù

Make sure your PR is from main ‚Üí main (on Student A‚Äôs repo)

Click Create pull request

‚úÖ Your caught-up contribution is now ready for review!





Open the pull request

Check the changes

Click Merge pull request ‚Üí Confirm merge

üéâ Now the main branch has clean history and includes both contributions!




You now know how to:

Fork and clone a GitHub repository
Work on a feature branch
Merge changes onto the latest main
Submit a clean pull request

‚ú® You‚Äôve just used a professional Git workflow!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn:

How to cross-reference sections, figures, code chunks, and tables in Quarto.
How to use a .gitignore file to keep unnecessary files out of your Git repository.



library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)



Quarto lets you easily refer to other parts of your document, like code, figures, and sections ‚Äî just like in academic papers.
Let‚Äôs walk through some examples using the palmerpenguins dataset.



Any heading can be cross-referenced by adding an ID to it:
## Data Cleaning {#sec-cleaning}
Now you can refer to it elsewhere like this:
See Section @sec-cleaning for details on how the data was prepared.




To reference a figure, give it a label and caption:
```{r}
#| label: fig-bill
#| fig-cap: "Bill length vs flipper length"
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_point()
```
Then reference it:
Figure @fig-bill shows the relationship between flipper length and bill length.



You can also label tables:
```{r}
#| label: tbl-summary
#| tbl-cap: "Summary statistics of the penguins dataset"
knitr::kable(summary(penguins))
```
Then refer to it like this:
See Table @tbl-summary for summary statistics of the dataset.
‚úÖ Try It Yourself:

Create a section, figure, and code chunk using the penguins data
Give each one a label
Add a sentence that references each one





When using Git, you often don‚Äôt want to track certain files (e.g., temporary files, data, or system files). That‚Äôs where .gitignore comes in!



A .gitignore file tells Git what to ignore ‚Äî Git will pretend these files don‚Äôt exist.
Example contents of .gitignore:
.Rproj.user
*.html
*.csv
.DS_Store
This would ignore:

RStudio project files
All .html and .csv files
macOS system files






In your project folder, create a file called .gitignore
Add the files or patterns you want Git to ignore
Save the file
Add a CSV file to your project folder
Check what Git sees:

git status
‚úÖ If the ignored files aren‚Äôt listed, .gitignore is working.




If you already added a file to Git before putting it in .gitignore, Git will still track it.
To stop tracking it:
git rm --cached filename.csv
Then commit:
git commit -m "Stop tracking filename.csv"






Use .gitignore to keep your Git repository clean
Avoid committing files like datasets, HTML outputs, or IDE settings
Helps keep collaboration and version control simple

üéâ Great job ‚Äî your Git repo is now cleaner and more professional!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üõ†Ô∏è Goal
Learn how to: - Save changes using git stash - Switch branches safely - Reapply your stashed work

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Step-by-Step Instructions

Make sure you‚Äôre inside a Git-tracked project (any project will do).
Open a file and make some changes ‚Äî but don‚Äôt commit yet.
Check your Git status:

git status
You should see the file listed as modified.


üì¶ 1. Stash Your Changes
Run:
git stash
‚úÖ This saves your changes and returns your working directory to a clean state.



üîÑ 2. Switch Branches (or Pull)
Now try switching to another branch:
git checkout main
Or do a pull:
git pull
‚úÖ Your working directory stays clean ‚Äî no conflicts!



‚ôªÔ∏è 3. Reapply the Stash
When you‚Äôre ready to bring back your changes:
git stash apply
‚úÖ Your edits will be restored to the files you changed.



üóëÔ∏è 4. (Optional) Clear the Stash
After applying, you can remove the stash:
git stash drop
Or, to both apply and drop in one step:
git stash pop

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚úÖ Try It

Modify a file

Run git stash

Switch branches

Return to your branch and run git stash apply

Confirm your changes are back

Commit if needed!


üéâ You‚Äôve learned how to pause your work safely and come back to it later!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Stashing
‚ÄúStashing takes the‚Äùdirty‚Äù state of your working directory - that is, your modified tracked files and staged changes - and saves it on a stack of unfinished changes that you can reapply at any time (even on a different branch).‚Äù Source
git stash comes in handy for staged files or `git stash -u for unstaged files.
git stash allow us to keep changes in our local repository and to commit then later on.
git stash save "Message" allow us to add a message to the stash

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash
Creating a stash allows you to revert but save changes that you might have done in the repository, without losing them.
Then, when you are ready to include those changes and to commit them into the remote repo we can use:

git stash apply makes your changes in the stash on the branch but keeps them in the stash.
git stash pop makes your changes in the stash on the branch and removes them from the stash.

Generally, pop is preferred unless you have to apply your changes more than once.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash in practice
$ git status
On branch master
Changes to be committed:
new file: style.css
Changes not staged for commit:
modified: index.html
$ git stash
Saved working directory and index state WIP on master: 
5002d47 our new homepage
HEAD is now at 5002d47 our new homepage

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git status changes after stashing
$ git status
On branch master
nothing to commit, working tree clean

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: While your changes are stashed you can ‚Ä¶
text:
While your changes are stashed you can ‚Ä¶

Make more changes into the repo, create new commits, switch branches and perform any other Git operations.
You can come back to your stash later on and re-apply your stash when you‚Äôre ready.
Stash is local to your repository.







Important


stashes are not transferred to the server when you push.



You can create more than one stash: be careful with this.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: git apply and git pop: stage changes
text:
git apply and git pop: stage changes
The git stash command takes your uncommitted changes but staged and saves them away for later use, or git stash -u if we have not staged the changes, and then reverts them from your working copy. git stash save ‚ÄúMessage to remember what you did‚Äù
To bring stash in from the repo:

git stash apply
git stash pop

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash apply
git stash apply will take the changes saved in your stash and apply them into the working directory of your current branch. In addition, the changes are kept in the stash. This might be useful when you want to apply the same changes into different branches.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash pop
git stash pop will do the same as apply but will delete the stash after applying the changes.






Important


The stash is not a replacement for a commit. You can think of stashing as ‚Äòkeeping for later‚Äô, while a commit is for saving and keeping record.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash pop in practice
$ git status
On branch master
nothing to commit, working tree clean
$ git stash pop
On branch master
Changes to be committed:
new file: style.css
Changes not staged for commit:
modified: index.html
Dropped refs/stash@{0} (32b3aa1d185dfe6d57b3c3cc3)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git stash apply in practice
git stash apply
On branch master
Changes to be committed:
new file: style.css
Changes not staged for commit:
modified: index.html

Do you see the difference between pop and apply?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Deleting stash

git stash drop stash@{0} will delete stash@{0}
git stash clear will remove all the stashes in the stash area.







Important


Because stashes aren‚Äôt synchronised, once they‚Äôre gone they‚Äôre gone. So, clear with caution.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Creating a branch from a stash
text:
Creating a branch from a stash
If you stash some work, leave it there for a while, and continue on the branch from which you stashed the work, you may have a problem reapplying the work. If the apply tries to modify a file that you‚Äôve since modified, you‚Äôll get a merge conflict and will have to try to resolve it.
If you want an easier way to test the stashed changes again, you can run git stash branch branchname, which creates a new branch for you with your selected branch name, checks out the commit you were on when you stashed your work, reapplies your work there, and then drops the stash if it applies successfully.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Tracked, untracked and ignored files
Git sees every file in your working copy as one of three things:

tracked: a file which has been previously staged or committed
untracked: a file which has not been staged or committed or
ignored: a file which Git has been explicitly told to ignore.

Typically in a project there might be files that we decided to not track and ignore.
Examples include files that are built artifacts and machine generated files that can be derived from your repository source or should otherwise not be committed.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
In Rstudio

Blue-M: a file that is already under version control that has been modified.
Orange-?: a file that is not under version control (yet‚Ä¶).
Green-A: a file that was not under version control, but which has been staged to be committed
Red-D: a file under version control has been deleted. To make it really disappear, you have to staged its disappearance and commit.
Purple-R: a file that was renamed. (Note that git in Rstudio seems to be figuring this out on its own.)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
.gitignore
Ignored files are tracked in a special file named .gitignore that is checked in at the root of your repository.

There is no explicit git ignore command: instead Git uses a .gitignore file which must be edited and committed by hand when you have new files that you wish to ignore.
.gitignore files contain special patterns which are comapred against filenames to determine whether or not they should be ignored.

.Ruserdata

*-Ex.R

Creating a gitignore file


From the command line you can create a .gitignore file for your repository.
touch .gitignore

You can also create a .gitignore file from GitHub.

You can edit it later using RStudio or VSCode.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Creating a .gitignore file
If you want to ignore a file that is already checked in, you have to untrack it before you add it to the .gitignore.
Do to this, from your terminal/Git Bash Shell:
$ git rm --cached FILENAME
The gitignore file specifies intentionally untracked files to ignore.
Each line in a gitignore file specifies a pattern.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Your branch is ahead of ‚Äòorigin/master‚Äô by 1 commits
text:
Your branch is ahead of ‚Äòorigin/master‚Äô by 1 commits

This message means that your local repository has one commit that hasn‚Äôt been pushed yet.
If you push without committing, nothing gets pushed.
If you commit without adding, nothing gets committed.
If you add without committing, nothing at all happens, git merely remembers that the changes you added should be considered for the following commit.







Tip


git add and git commit are local operations.
git push, git pull, and git fetch are operations that interact with a remote repository.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Why do we fork a repository?
text:
Why do we fork a repository?
A fork is a copy of a repository.

Forking a repository allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project.
Most commonly, forks are used to either propose changes to someone else project or to use someone else project as a starting point for your own project.0

More info here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Differences between forking and cloning a repo
text:
Differences between forking and cloning a repo

A fork is a copy of someone else GitHub repository, saved to your own GitHub. It allows you to experiment with changes without affecting the original project.
A fork acts as a bridge between the original repository and your personal one.
It will also allow you to interact between your forked copy and the original repo.



When you clone a GitHub repository, you are creating a local copy of that repo on your computer.
That allows you to work on that repo locally and sync between both your local repo and your remote repo, but you cannot interact with the original repo if it‚Äôs owned by someone else.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
What is a Pull request?

We use GitHub to share our code and projects with others.
There are situations when another person makes changes into your code and wants you to consider those changes, for example fixing a bug or adding new examples

To do this, the other person can make a pull request. This makes a request to the repositories owner to pull or merge these changes into the original repository.

text:
Creating a new project
Let‚Äôs practice creating a new project from scratch. We will start by making the remote repository in GitHub.

Go to https://github.com and log in.
Click the + icon in the top-right corner ‚Üí choose ‚ÄúNew repository‚Äù.
Fill out the form:

Repository name: e.g., my-new-project
(Optional) Add a short description
Choose Public (or Private if preferred)
‚úÖ Check ‚ÄúAdd a README file‚Äù

Click the ‚ÄúCreate repository‚Äù button at the bottom.

Your repository is now created and ready to use!
Now, we need to clone the repository.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: üíª Step 2: Clone the Repository Using the Terminal
text:
üíª Step 2: Clone the Repository Using the Terminal

On your new repository page, click the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button.
Choose the SSH tab (‚ö†Ô∏è not HTTPS) and copy the URL.
It will look like this:
git@github.com:your-username/my-new-project.git
Open your terminal.
Navigate to the folder where you want to store your project (e.g., Documents):
cd ~/Documents
Use the git clone command followed by the URL:
git clone git@github.com:your-username/my-new-project.git
Move into the project folder:
cd my-new-project

````markdown ## üåø Step 3: Create a Branch, Make Changes, and Push
Now that your repository is cloned, you‚Äôre ready to create a branch, make some changes, and push it to GitHub.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Exercise 2: Git and GitHub configuration

1. Git configuration
Open your command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash Shell window and type the following:






Important



Please replace ‚ÄúFirstname lastname‚Äù with your own details and choose a name that is identifiable for credit (this information is the one that identifies you)


git config --global user.name "Firstname lastname"
Set your Monash email address to be associated with each history commit:
git config --global user.email "valid email address"
Now go to your Rstudio session and follow the next steps:

Select Tools from the menu and go to Global Options
Click Git/SVN on the left panel
Click Enable version control interface for RStudio projects at the top and continue with the steps below.

Next we are going to create an SSH key as follows (we want to do this to avoid having to input our GitHub credentials each time we interact with GitHub):

Click on Create SSH Key and another pop-up prompt will appear where you will be asked to provide a PassPhrase. You do not need a passphrase. It is considered more secure but be aware you will have to enter this phrase as a password every time when the key is used.







Click View public key and copy the key to the clipboard (ctrl c (Windows) or command c (mac)).







Navigate to GitHub and go to the top right corner where your avatar is, select your avatar and select Settings from the drop-down menu.







Go to SSH and GPG keys item in the left side menu inside your GitHub account. Click the green ‚ÄúNew SSH key‚Äù button and give your key a title and paste the key you copy from Rstudio in the step above into the Key text-box. Then click ‚ÄúAdd SSH key‚Äù.

The process described above allows you to interact between your local Git and GitHub without having to write your GitHub logging details each time you do a git operation between your local and your remote repository.


2. Creating a repository on GitHub
Using your internet browser:

Log in into your GitHub account following this link
Create a new private repo called Tutorial3 and make sure the repo is initialized with a README.md file by ticking on the option ‚ÄúInitialize this repository with a README‚Äù at the bottom of the page.
Click the name Tutorial3 to look inside your GitHub project, identify what is the HTTPS and SSH address of this project by looking at the green tab (code).

See below the solutions:

















3. Cloning and modifying our first GitHub repo using our Terminal/Command line interface/Git Bash shell and with Rstudio
Using your internet browser:

Clone the GitHub repository that you created in the previous exercise in your computer using the command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash shell. Remember that it is very important that you first decide where you want to clone the project in your computer and you navigate to that location using the command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash shell.

The git command to clone a GitHub repo is git clone SSH-repo GitHub path (SSH-repo GitHub path refers to the path that you will fine in your GitHub project page under Code > SSH and copy the address that you see, it will end in .git. Mine looks like this
git@github.com:ETC5513demo/Tutorial3.git
Then proceed to clone the repository in your local machine using the command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash shell:
git clone  git@github.com:github.com/ETC5513demo/Tutorial3.git (replace the SSH with your own!)
(you can obtain this from within your GitHub project ‚Äì> code)

You will be prompted to input your GitHub log in details (only for this time). Enter your GitHub user name and password
Open your Rstudio and create a New Project associated with the folder of the GitHub repository that you just cloned in step 1:

Projects > Create a New project > From an existing directory
From the bottom left pane in your Rstudio open the README.md file and add the following sentence:
‚ÄúThis repository is an example about how to integrate GitHub with Rstudio‚Äù

In your command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash shell type git status and observe that the file has been marked as modified.
Add this file to the staging area, create a commit and push the changes to the remote repository using our command line interface/Terminal/Git Bash shell.
Hints: git add filename; git commit -m "Commit message"; git push origin main. Remember that you can use git status at anytime during this process to see the status of your git repository. In summary:

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Exercise 2: Command line interface & git
Here, we will use your Terminal/command line interface/Gitbash to interact between your local repository and your remote repository

Continue working in the Rstudio Project that you created in the previous exercise. Inside your Rstudio project, copy the qmd file we made in Week 2 over to this directory.







Tip



You can do this either in your file explorer, or for an extra challenge, using the terminal.



Do the same process with the data folder from Week 2.
Now we are going to use your Terminal/command line interface/Gitbash to commit the changes using the directly. Please type the following in your Terminal/command line interface/Gitbash:


git add . (or git add * to commit all the changes)
git commit -m "Adding folder data"
git push origin main


General workflow to interact with GitHub using the Terminal:


git clone (A repository is typically clone only one time from the remote repository)
git pull (The git pull command is used to fetch and download content from a remote repository and immediately update the local repository to match that content. You should do this every time you star working in your local repository)
git status (The git status command displays the state of the working directory and the staging area)
git add <file_name> (The git add command adds a change in the working directory to the staging area)
git add * (Will commit all the changes)
git commit -m "Message"(m = message for commit. The git commit is used to create a snapshot of the staged changes along a timeline of a Git projects history.)
git push origin <branch_name> (The git push command is used to upload local repository content to a remote repository. )

dat <- read_csv("data/avian_influenza_numbers.csv")

Modify the head command to display 10 rows.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Exercise 4: Data Wrangling

Using the R package dplyr (which is loaded with tidyverse), and using the pipe (|>), create a new dataset called data_cleaned that only contains the following variables:

Month
Australia
Egypt
United States



Inspect data_cleaned and describe using a markdown list the type of variables in this new dataset. Write the names of the variables in bold. Do you think the variable attributes are correct?


Convert the variable date into a date vector using lubridate::mdy. What do you notice?


Remove cases for which the data is aggregated or doesn‚Äôt have a valid month.


What is the dimension of this new data set? Compare it with the dimension of cleaned_data. How many cases have we lost?


Provide a table summary of the three countries using the kable() function from the kableExtra package. Give it the caption ‚ÄúSummary of number of cases of Avian Influenza‚Äù.


Visualize the case counts using a histogram and give an explanation about the information that a histogram convey. In addition change the x label in the plot to Age and remove the y axis label.
Hint: As a first step, do this for just one country. To do multiple countries at once, you will need to pivot_longer your dataset.


Extension: Change this plot to a time series plot, with one bar per month. As an extra challenge, split this out into three separate plots - one per country.

The data for the tutorial is inside a folder called data, which is bundled with the RStudio Project you made in this week‚Äôs workshop. Find that file in the lower right pane where all your files are listed.

dat <- read_csv("data/avian_influenza_numbers.csv")

Insert a new R Chunk and find out what information you can get from the command head(dat)
Modify the head command to display 10 rows.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Exercise 4: Data Wrangling

Using the R package dplyr (which is loaded with tidyverse), and using the pipe (|>), create a new dataset called data_cleaned that only contains the following variables:

Month
Australia
Egypt
United States








Solution






data_cleaned <- dat |>
    select(Month, Australia, Egypt, `United States`)





Inspect data_cleaned and describe using a markdown list the type of variables in this new dataset. Write the names of the variables in bold. Do you think the variable attributes are correct?







Solution






* `Month` is a character (`<chr>`)
* `Australia`, `Egypt` and `United States` are character (`<chr>`)
We would expect Month to be a date





Convert the variable date into a date vector using lubridate::mdy. What do you notice?







Solution






Let‚Äôs put it in a new object

data_monthly <- data_cleaned |>
    mutate(monthdate = lubridate::mdy(Month))

There are some missing values. If we filter by these,

data_monthly |> filter(is.na(monthdate))

# A tibble: 32 √ó 5
   Month Australia Egypt `United States` monthdate
   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>           <dbl> <date>   
 1 <NA>         NA    NA              NA NA       
 2 <NA>         NA    NA              NA NA       
 3 <NA>         NA    NA              NA NA

 5 1998          0     0               0 NA       
 6 1999          0     0               0 NA

10 2003          0     0               0 NA       
# ‚Ñπ 22 more rows


We see it seems to be aggregated data that is NA, so we can safely ignore them.

data_monthly <- data_monthly |> filter(!is.na(monthdate))






Remove cases for which the data is aggregated or doesn‚Äôt have a valid month.







Solution







data_monthly <- data_monthly |> filter(!is.na(monthdate))






What is the dimension of this new data set? Compare it with the dimension of cleaned_data. How many cases have we lost?







Solution







dim(data_monthly)

[1] 338   5

dim(data_cleaned)

[1] 370   4


We have lost 32 cases for which we did not have information about age or gender.





Provide a table summary of the three countries using the kable() function from the kableExtra package. Give it the caption ‚ÄúSummary of number of cases of Avian Influenza‚Äù.







Solution







library(knitr)
data_monthly |>
    select(Egypt, Australia, `United States`) |>
    summary() |>
    kable(caption = "COVID-19 Age Summary")

Visualize the case counts using a histogram and give an explanation about the information that a histogram convey. In addition change the x label in the plot to Age and remove the y axis label.
Hint: As a first step, do this for just one country. To do multiple countries at once, you will need to pivot_longer your dataset.







Solution







library(ggplot2)
data_monthly |>
    ggplot(aes(x=Egypt)) +
    geom_histogram(binwidth = 5) +
    labs(x="Case counts in Egypt", y="")









library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
data_monthly |>
    # Drop the old month column
    select(!Month) |>
    # Pivot everything except monthdate
    pivot_longer(!monthdate) |>
    ggplot(aes(x=value, fill = name)) +
    geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, position = "dodge") +
    labs(x="Case counts of Avian Influenza", y="")













Extension: Change this plot to a time series plot, with one bar per month. As an extra challenge, split this out into three separate plots - one per country.







Solution







data_monthly |>
    # Drop the old month column
    select(!Month) |>
    # Pivot everything except monthdate
    pivot_longer(!monthdate) |>
    ggplot(aes(x=monthdate, y = value, fill = name)) +
    geom_col() +
    facet_wrap(~name, scales="free") +
    labs(x="Case counts of Avian Influenza", y="")


















Important



At the end of this tutorial, you should have a full QMD file that renders, including your code and the outputs from it. This means you can read it from top to bottom and remember what you did.

title: Making sure your code is transportable
text:
It used to work I‚Äôm sure!



My code ran 6 months ago (I‚Äôm sure it did) and now it is not working.
My figures in ggplot look funny now


Generally, this is because a version of a package has updated.












The primary solution for dependency management (which is far from perfect) is renv





The idea is to create a project-specific library to ensure a project has a record of which version of R packages are used.




Gives each R project it‚Äôs own local library
Provides an easy way to get R sessions to use a local library
Provides tools for managing the R packages installed in these local libraries









When we load a library, what exactly is going on?

R searches in a collection of places for the dplyr package, and loads it.
These places are called library paths.


You can change the library path, and you can view them using .libPaths()




Your default library path is probably something like:
/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/4.0/Resources/library
If you want to find a package, you can use find.package("dplyr")

renv sets up a project-specific library path to keep your packages from interacting with eaach other.




Via the R console:

renv::init() to initialise the project
Work as usual, installing packages, writing code
renv::snapshot() to save the state of the local library to a lockfile
renv::restore() to reverty our packages to the state encoded in the lockfile

The lockfile contains all the information about which package version is being used, and makes your environment reproducible.



In collaborative projects, you may want to ensure everyone is working with the same environment
It helps protect against changes between different versions of packages.

By sharing the lockfile, your collaborators will be using the same version of packages that you are using, without breaking their own installs.

title: Making sure your code is transportable
text:
Managing the lockfile
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre using a version control system with your project, then as you call renv::snapshot() and later commit new lockfiles to your repository, you may find it necessary later to recover older versions of your lockfiles. renv provides the functions renv::history() to list previous revisions of your lockfile, and renv::revert() to recover these older lockfiles.‚Äù
Currently, only Git repositories are supported by renv::history() and renv::revert().
Source here

title: Making sure your code is transportable
text:
Managing the lockfile
Each project contains only a single renv.lock
There are some helper functions:

renv::history(): find prior commtis in which the lockfile has changed
renv::revert(commit = SHA1): Revert the lockfile to a state at a previous commit







Important



Make sure to commit the lockfile often, and call renv::snapshot() when you‚Äôre updating packages! This is the only way the changes can be recorded and shared.

title: Making sure your code is transportable
text:
Workflow for collaboration

Select a version control system (i.e.¬†git and GitHub)
Initialise the project: renv::init()
Periodically, and after adding new packages, use renv::snapshot()
Stage, commit and share renv.lock with others via version control.

title: Making sure your code is transportable
text:
Workflow for collaboration
Once collaborators clone the repository, they also run renv::init().
This will automatically install the packages declared in the lockfile.
By doing this, they can work in your project using exactly the same R packages that you used when the lockfile was generated.

text:
ETC5513 Unit Objectives

Develop skills to create reproducible documents.
Understand the operation of version control systems.
Advance use of version control.
Utilize version control to integrate data analysis efforts of team members.
Effectively work with a group to construct a collaborative data science project.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Reproducibility and Replicability
Definitions by the USA National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine:






Tip


Reproducibility (‚Äúcomputational reproducibility‚Äù) means obtaining consistent computational results using the same input data, computational steps, methods, code, and conditions of analysis.



Replicability means obtaining consistent results across studies aimed at answering the same scientific question, each of which has obtained its own data

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Reproducible research

Working to make your research reproducible does require extra upfront effort.
Making a project reproducible from the start encourages you to use better work habits.
It should push you to bring your data and source code up to a higher level of quality than you might if you ‚Äúthought ‚Äòno one was looking‚Äô‚Äù [Donoho, 2010, 386].
Reproducible research needs to be stored so that other researchers can actually access the data and source code.
Changes are easier to implement \(\rightarrow\) specially when using dynamic reproducible documents.
Reproducible research has higher impact.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Tools for reproducible research

R programming language

R enables researchers to read data, create data visualizations and run statistical analyses.
R has thousands of libraries
R has a very active development community that is constantly expanding.

R libraries/packages facilitate reproducibility:

Knitr and Rmarkdown:

Allow us to connect R-based analyses to presentation, papers and reports documents created with markup languages such as LaTeX and Markdown

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rstudio

RStudio is an integrated developer environment (IDE):

R by itself has the capabilities necessary to gather and analyze data, and with a little help from knitr/Rmarkdown and markup languages, present results in a way that is highly reproducible.


RStudio allows you to do all of these things more easily. - It also is a happy medium between R‚Äôs text-based interface and a pure GUI. - It is not the only IDE! - It is closely integrated with the version control programs Git and SVN.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Version control






Tip


Version Control is a system that records changes to a file or set of files over time so that you can recall specific versions later.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git
‚ÄúGit is a distributed version-control system for tracking changes in source code during software development. It is designed for coordinating work among programmers, but it can be used to track changes in any set of files. Its goals include speed, data integrity, and support for distributed, non-linear workflows‚Äù
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
R code chunks
You can quickly insert R chunks into your file with

the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + Alt + I (OS X: Cmd + Option + I)
the Add Chunk command in the editor toolbar
or by typing the chunk delimiters

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Chunk options
Chunk output can be customized with options, marked by the ‚Äúhashpipe‚Äù: #|

include: false prevents code and results from appearing in the finished file. Quarto still runs the code in the chunk, and the results can be used by other chunks.
echo: false prevents code, but not the results from appearing in the finished file. This is a useful way to embed figures.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
More R code chunk options

eval: false prevents evaluating the code and include its results
message: false prevents messages that are generated by code from appearing in the finished file.
warning: false prevents warnings that are generated by code from appearing in the finished.
fig-cap: ... adds a caption to graphical results.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: R code chunks

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Global options
To set global options that apply to every chunk in your file, call
knitr::opts_chunk$set()
in an R code chunk.
Knitr will treat each option that you pass to knitr::opts_chunk$set() as a global default that can be overwritten in individual R code chunk headers.
More info here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Caching

If document rendering becomes time consuming due to long computations you can use knitr caching to improve performance.
Knitr chunk and package options (here) describes how caching works
The cache examples (here) provide additional details.

cache: true is an option within the chunks or you can set it as a global option.






Caution


Caching might prevent you from updating some results. Because of that, it is essential that you use it only when you are sure your R code chunks are working fine. Setting cache = TRUE as a global option might be dangerous so be very careful.

Computer paths: Absolute and Relative Paths
An absolute or full path begins with a drive letter followed by a colon, such as D: or /users.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Three Git States
Git has three main states that your files can reside in: modified, staged, and committed:

Modified: you have changed the file but have not committed it to your database yet.
Staged: you have marked a modified file in its current version to go into your next commit snapshot.
Committed: the data is safely stored in your local database.

This leads us to the three main sections of a Git project: the working tree, the staging area, and the Git directory.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git recap

Tracking all the changes to a project
Allows you to go back and forth between versions
Check files history
Tag specific versions for quick referencing
Review changes made by collaborators in the project
Create project branches that allow you to work on the project withoutinterfering with the main project
Merging branches to main project

To interact between our projects and Git, we are going to use the shell/command line interface

From clone to push into the remote main branch

git clone: is a Git command line utility which is used to target an existing repository and create a clone, or copy of the target repository.
git add: command adds a change in the working directory to the staging area.
git commit -m: The git commit command captures a snapshot of the project‚Äôs currently staged changes. (m = message for commit. The git commit is used to create a snapshot of the staged changes along a timeline of a Git projects history.)
git push origin main: The git push command is used to upload local repository content to a remote repository, in this case to the main branch.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Tracked and untracked files

In a git repository tracked files are those which are part of the git repository
However, we can also have untracked files for which their history is not tracked
Tracked files are files that were in the last snapshot; they can be unmodified, modified, or staged. In short, tracked files are files that Git knows about.
Untracked files are everything else ‚Äî any files in your working directory that were not in your last snapshot and are not in your staging area.

More info here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
General Workflow (via Terminal)
Once you have cloned the repo, each time you work on the project (via the terminal/command line):

git pull: used to fetch and download content from a remote repository and immediately update the local repository to match that content.
git status: displays the state of the working directory and the staging area
git add file_name: adds changes in the working directory to the staging area)
git commit -m "Message": used to create a snapshot of the staged changes along a timeline of a Git project history
git push origin branch name: used to upload the local repository content to a remote repository in GitHub

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rstudio and GitHub
Understanding the symbols in the Rstudio Git pane:

Blue-M: a file that is already under version control that has been modified.
Orange-?: a file that is not under version control (yet‚Ä¶)
Green-A: a file that was not under version control, but which has been staged to be committed.
Red-D: a file under version control has been deleted. To make it really disappear, you have to stage its disappearance and commit.
Purple-R: a file that was renamed. (Note that git in Rstudio seems to be figuring this out on its own.)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Branches

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Create branches using the Terminal/Shell/CLI
Using git branch and git checkout:

git branch show us the branches we have in our repo and marked our current branch with *
git branch newbranch_name creates a new branch but does not move the HEAD of the repo there.
git checkout newbranch_name moves the HEAD to newbranch_name

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Creating branches
Using the checkout command:

git checkout -b newbranch_namne: creates a new branch and moves the repo HEAD to this branch
You can confirm it by using git branch to see in which branch you are currently in
Checking out a branch updates the files in the working directory to match the version stored in that branch
It tells Git to record all new commits on that branch.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Merging branches successfully
Suppose we have two branches: main and new_development

For merging: go to main branch git checkout main
git merge new_development -m "Merging new_development into main"

Remember that if you have VSCode installed and you do git merge new_development then the VSCode editor will open so that you can type your message.
If those steps are successful your new_development branch will be fully integrated within the main branch.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Change branch name
Before you push the new branch to the remote repo:
git branch -m original_name new_name
If you want to renamed a branch that has already been pushed to the remote repo:

Rename the branch locally git branch -m old_name_branch new_name
git push origin -u newname
Delete the old_name_branch: git push origin --delete old_name_branch

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Stash changes: Apply and pop
The git stash command takes your uncommitted changes and saves them in the git repo away for later use.
Bringing stash into the repo

git stash
git stash apply
git stash pop
git stash list to see the list of the stashes

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Apply
git stash apply will take the changes saved in your stash and apply them into the working directory of your current branch. In addition, the changes are kept in the stash.
This might be useful when you want to apply the same changes into different branches.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Pop
git stash pop will do the same as apply but will delete the stash after applying the changes. git stash pop will apply the changes into your working copy.






Tip


Stash is not a substitute for committing changes

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
gitignore

Ignored files are tracked in a special file named .gitignore that is checked in at the root of your repository.
There is no explicit git ignore command: instead Git uses a .gitignore file which must be edited and committed by hand when you have new files that you wish to ignore.
.gitignore files contain patterns that are matched against file names in your repository to determine whether or not they shouldbe ignored.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rebase in practice
Assume the following history exists and the current branch is ‚ÄúFeature‚Äù
          A---B---C Feature
         /
    D---E---F---G main
From this point, the result of either of the following commands:
git checkout Feature
git rebase main
git rebase main Feature
                  A'--B'--C' Feature
                  /
    D---E---F---G main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git rebase and merge
Merging is a non-destructive operation. The existing branches are not changed in any way. This avoids all of the potential problems of rebasing.
Rebasing moves the entire Feature branch to begin on the tip of the main branch, incorporating all of the new commits into main.
Rebasing re-writes the project history by creating brand new commits for each commit in the original branch. Produces cleaner project history.
However, it creates problems with safety and traceability
Golden rule for rebase: Never use it on public branches (main in collaborative projects).

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Why do we fork a repository?
text:
Why do we fork a repository?
A fork is a copy of a repository
Forking a repository allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project.
Most commonly, forks are used to either propose changes to someone else project or to use someone else project as a starting point for your own project.
More info here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Differences between forking and cloning a repo
text:
Differences between forking and cloning a repo

A fork is a copy of someone elses GitHub repository saved to your own GitHub account. It allows you to experiment with changes without affecting the original project.
A fork acts as a between the original repository and your personal one.
It will also allow you to interact between your forked copy and the original repo
When you clone a GitHub repository, you are creating a local copy of that repo on your computer
That allows you to work on that repo locally and sync between both your local repo and your remote repo

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
What is a Pull request?

We use GitHub to share our code and projects with others.
There are situations when another person make changes into your code and wants you to consider those changes.
Examples: Fixing a problem/bug or add new functionality into the repo.
We achieve this by sending a request to the repo‚Äôs owner to pull/merge these changes into the owner‚Äôs original GitHub repo

That request is called a pull request

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Detached HEAD
Detached HEAD state gives you the power to check out any commit and explore the older state of a repository without having to create a local branch.
Any commits made in a detached HEAD state will be lost when you check out any branch.
Solution: Create a branch to keep commits

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Pull commit from the log into our environment
text:
Pull commit from the log into our environment
git checkout 8cfaee1e447d8e8
You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
   changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
   state without impacting any branches by performing another checkout.
git checkout -b new_branch_name

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Stage and unstage files
git reset filename git reset

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Edit/Amend previous commit
If you have not pushed the commit: - git commit --amend: will open your VS code editor so you can amend the commit - git push origin main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git reset --soft
Imagine that you have added two files in your latest commit and you want to make a modification in one of the files.

In this case we can use git reset --soft HEAD~1 to undo our last commit and include additional modifications into the file.
In this case, when we undo the commit the file is still in the repo with changes to be committed but the commit has been removed.
We have undone the last commit by preserving the changes done to the files in the index (staging area).
Then we can fix the file and commit the changes again.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git reset --hard

If we want to undo the last commit and discard all changes in the working directory and index (staging area), we can execute the git reset command with the ‚Äì-hard option.
As before we specify the commit before HEAD (HEAD~1).







Caution


When we use git reset --hard all the changes will be removed from the working directory and from the index (staging area).

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git reset --mixed

If we want to undo the last Git commit, keep changes in the working directory but NOT in the index (staging area), we can use the git reset --mixed option.
For the last commit we will need to write git reset --mixed HEAD~1
The git reset --mixed option is combination of soft and hard reset.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Undoing
The git revert command can be considered an ‚Äòundo‚Äô type command, however, it is not a traditional undo operation. Instead of removing the commit from the project history, it figures out how to invert the changes introduced by the commit and appends a new commit with the resulting inverse content. This prevents Git from losing history, which is important for the integrity of your revision history and for reliable collaboration.
You can think of it as a ‚Äúrollback‚Äù: it points your local environment back to a previous commit. Your ‚Äúlocal environment,‚Äù refers to your local repository, staging area, and working directory

section: Large files in Git and GitHub
text:
Large files in Git and GitHub

Files larger than 100 MB need to be dealt with care in GitHub
Solution: Git LFS

Git Large File Storage lets you store them on a remote server such as GitHub.
More info here






Tip


Git Large File Storage (LFS) replaces large files such as audio samples, videos, data sets, and graphics with text pointers inside Git, while storing the file contents on a remote server like GitHub.com or GitHub Enterprise.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git LFS in practice summary

git lfs install: You only need to run this once per repo.
git lfs track "*.csv": In each Git repository where you want to use Git LFS, select the file types you would like Git LFS to manage
git add .gitattributes: make sure ‚Äú.gitattributes‚Äù is tracked

Then, continue as usual:

git add file.csv
git commit -m "Add data file"
git push origin main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git LFS in practice summary
If for some reason you have staged/committed a large file before you run the work flow above you can use:

git reset --soft HEAD~1

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git tags
Tags are references that point to specific points in Git history
Example: Specific report release, package release

A tag is like a branch that doesn‚Äôt change.
Unlike branches, tags (after being created) have no further history of commits

Great tutorial on tags here
