title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Exercise 2: Creating a branch
For this exercise, continue working in the same project as in Exercise 1

Use the terminal to create a new branch using git branch globaloptions
Switch to this branch using git switch globaloptions
Refresh your Rstudio to see which branch you are currently working in
Switch back to main using git switch main, and check you can see it in RStudio.
Switch again back to globaloptions
Delete the branch using git branch -d globaloptions. What error do you get?
Switch to main and again try to delete globaloptions
Re-create global options as in Step 2. Inside the week4.qmd, modify the YAML to include the following options:


execute:
    echo: false
    warning: false
    message: false

Stage, commit and push the changes to the remote repo in GitHub.
Check you can see the new branch on GitHub.


Extension
Merge the branch globaloptions into the main branch.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
In this exercise, you‚Äôll work with a partner to practice real-world collaboration on GitHub.
You‚Äôll learn how to:

Fork a GitHub repo created by your teammate
Make a change
Submit a pull request (PR)
Review and merge someone else‚Äôs PR




Assign roles in your pair:

Student A = Repository Owner

Student B = Contributor (forks and submits a pull request)

You‚Äôll switch roles after completing the exercise.





Go to https://github.com and log in.

Click + ‚Üí New Repository

Name the repository something simple, like collab-demo

‚úÖ Check Add a README file

Click Create Repository

Share the URL of the repository with Student B
Now clone the repository to your own computer:

Click the green Code button ‚Üí choose SSH and copy the URL

In your terminal:

git clone git@github.com:your-username/collab-demo.git
cd collab-demo
Create a new RStudio Project in an existing directory:

Open RStudio

Go to File ‚Üí New Project ‚Üí Existing Directory

Browse to the folder you just cloned (e.g., collab-demo)

Click Create Project

Add, commit and push the .Rproj file that gets created:
git add .Rproj
git commit -m "Add .Rproj file"
git push origin main

‚úÖ Done! Your repository is ready for your partner to fork and contribute.





Open the repo link your partner (Student A) shared.
Click the ‚ÄúFork‚Äù button (top-right corner).
On your forked copy, click Code ‚Üí SSH and copy the URL.
Open your terminal and clone your fork:

git clone git@github.com:your-username/collab-demo.git
cd collab-demo

Open this folder in RStudio and edit the README file to include your name
Save the file, then stage, commit, and push:

git add README.md
git commit -m "Add line to README"
git push origin main

Go back to your forked repository on GitHub.
Click ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù, then Create pull request.

‚úÖ You‚Äôve submitted your contribution!





Go to your original repository on GitHub.
You should see a new pull request from your partner.
Click it ‚Üí Review the changes.
Click Merge pull request, then Confirm merge.
(Optional) Delete the branch after merging.

üéâ Your teammate‚Äôs changes are now part of the main repository!




Switch roles so both students get experience creating, forking, and merging.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üì¶ Step 1: Fork the Repository

Go to this GitHub repository:
üëâ https://github.com/numbats/rcp
In the top-right corner, click the ‚ÄúFork‚Äù button.
GitHub will create a copy of the repo in your account.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üíª Step 2: Clone Your Fork

On your forked repository page, click the green Code button.

Select SSH, then copy the URL.
Open your terminal and run:

git clone git@github.com:your-username/rcp.git
cd rcp

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üìù Step 3: Add Your File
Inside the project, you‚Äôll see a folder called student-record.

Create a new file in that folder using your GitHub username. For example:

touch student-record/MikeLydeamore.md

Open the file and add a simple message:

Hi, I‚Äôm MikeLydeamore on GitHub! Here‚Äôs my contribution to the rcp project.

Save the file.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üì¨ Step 4: Commit and Push

Stage and commit your file:

git add student-record/jamie-lee.md
git commit -m "Add jamie-lee.md to student-record"

Push your changes to your fork:

git push origin main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚úÖ Step 5: Create a Pull Request

Go back to your fork on GitHub.

You should see a banner to ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù ‚Äî click it.

Confirm the changes, then click ‚ÄúCreate pull request‚Äù

üéâ You‚Äôve just submitted a real contribution to a public GitHub repository!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† Why This Matters
This is how open-source collaboration works in the real world:

You fork a project
Make meaningful changes
Propose those changes via a pull request
Maintainers review and (hopefully!) merge your work

You‚Äôre now part of the open-source ecosystem üí™

text:
ETC5513: Reproducible and Collaborative Practices
Reproducible reporting and version control systems
Lecturer: Michael Lydeamore
Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics




michael.lydeamore@monash.edu


 Week 6


rcp.numbat.space

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Open Frame

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Recap

More Git/GitHub tools
Pull requests: a tool to collaborate with others via GitHub
VSCode

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Today‚Äôs plan






Aim



Learn about git rebase
Learn about git fetch and git merge
Learn about staging and unstaging files
Learn how to undo some changes

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rebase
In git, there are two main ways to integrate changes from one branch into another:

git merge
git rebase

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Merging branches using git merge
If we use git merge to combine diverging branches, we will have a non-linear history.




















Question


In which situation can we merge branches and have a linear history?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rebase
Rebasing is the process of moving or combining a sequence of commits from a branch onto another branch.

Rebasing is most useful and easily visualised in the context of a feature branching workflow
Rebasing changes the base of your branch from one commit to another, making it appear as though you‚Äôd created your branch from a different commit.







Important


Rebasing moves an entire branch to another location in the repository



It can create a cleaner history if you don‚Äôt want merge lines everywhere.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Rebase in practice
Assume the following history exists and the current branch is feature:
          E<---F<---G feature
         /
    A<---B<---C<---D main
If we want to rebase the commits in the feature branch into the main branch, we need to do the following:



git checkout feature and
git rebase main

or

git rebase main feature


        feature    E'<--F'<--G' 
                  /
 A<---B<---C<---D main


which results in:
   A<---B<---C<---D<---E'<--F'<--G' main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Rebasing can be dangerous

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git rebase and merge

Merging is a non-destructive operation. The existing branches are not changed in any way, and this avoids all the potential problems of rebasing.
Rebasing moves the entire feature branch to begin on the tip of the main branch, incorporating all of the new commits into main.
Rebasing rewrites the project history by creating brand new commits for each commit in the original branch, giving a cleaner history
However, this creates problems with safety and traceability







Golden rule for rebase


Never use it on public branches (such as main) in collaborative projects.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
More on branching
Imagine that you are working on your local repository and a collaborator has created a new branch in your remote repo. You are currently working on your local repo and want to have a look at the new branch. That means that the local repo and your remote repo have diverged. That is, both the local and remote repositories are not currently synchronized.

To synchronize your work: git fetch origin
git fetch origin looks where origin is and fetches any data from it that you don‚Äôt yet have.
It also updates your local database repo, moving your origin/main pointer (HEAD) to its new, more up-to-date position. However, it does not move the HEAD of your local repository

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
About remotes
Note: If a git repo contains more than one remote, then git fetch will fetch all the changes from all remotes.
To fetch only one, use git fetch origin (or whatever remote you are after).

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
How does fetch work?

git fetch downloaded the new B commit however our local working directory is not updated, and the head of our main branch is still pointing to commit A.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: How do we merge those branches?
text:
How do we merge those branches?
We need to combined main branch with the remote tracking origin/main branch. How?

By merging!


First, we need to move in the main branch and then merge origin/main
git checkout main
git merge origin/main


If the branches have not diverged, we can merge without conflict via a ‚Äòfast merge‚Äô.
If the branches have diverged, we will need to resolve conflicts.
You can check the status of the local and remote branches by using git branch -vv

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Very useful commands for fetching

git remote lets you create, view, and delete connections to remote repositories.
git branch -vv allows you to check the status of your local and remote branches in relation to each other.
git fetch origin fetches the changes from remote origin
git branch -a lists all the branches available in the local repository + all the branches fetched from the remote.







Tip


The branches fetched from the remote origin would be preceded by remotes/origin/

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Undoing an error
Not everything we do on a project will be worth keeping. We‚Äôve seen already one way to undo some work (git stash). But, that relies on not having already committed the changes.
What if we‚Äôve made a commit, and then realise we don‚Äôt want that commit anymore?

We can reset


Or revert

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Undoing an error
First, we should discuss checkout. We‚Äôve talked alot about HEAD - that‚Äôs the current pointer of the repository.
We‚Äôve seen git checkout before too: When swapping between branches!
Fundamentally, branches are just commits with a slightly different pointer. That means, we can checkout to a specific commit.

One option to go backwards on the git tree and make a new set of changes is to checkout to a commit hash, make the new changes, and then push and manage the merge conflicts.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Undoing an error
Here‚Äôs our git tree:
(a) --- (b) --- (c) --- (d) <- HEAD, main

When we checkout b, our git tree changes to:
(a) --- (b) --- (c) --- (d) <- main
          \ 
          HEAD


Note that doing this will create diverging histories and so is generally to be avoided. You can overwrite history using git push -f, but this is really discouraged.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Reset or Revert
There are two ways to change commit history of a repository: reset and revert.






Tip


Generally, reset is for when the commit isn‚Äôt public, and revert is when you‚Äôve already made a public commit.




This is because reset changes the commit history, and revert does not.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üõë Two Very Different Tools








Command
What it does
Safe on shared branches?




git revert
Adds a new commit that undoes changes
‚úÖ Yes


git reset
Moves branch pointer (can erase commits)
‚ùå Use with caution

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üîÅ git revert

Safely undoes a specific commit
Leaves history intact
Perfect for undoing mistakes on main or shared branches

git revert <commit-hash>

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
‚úçÔ∏è git revert Example
You added a bad commit:
git log --oneline
Find the commit to undo, then:
git revert abc1234
‚úÖ Creates a new commit that reverses the changes

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üßπ git reset

Rewrites history ‚ö†Ô∏è

Used to go back in time

3 types: --soft, --mixed, --hard

git reset --hard HEAD~1

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Reset Variants
--soft

Undo commit, keep staged changes

git reset --soft HEAD~1
--mixed (default)

Undo commit, keep unstaged changes

git reset HEAD~1
--hard

‚ö†Ô∏è DANGEROUS: Lose commits and file changes

git reset --hard HEAD~1

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üîç Visualizing Revert vs Reset
Original history:
A --- B --- C --- D   (main)

You realize C introduced a bug‚Ä¶
git revert C:

A --- B --- C --- D --- E   ‚Üê E undoes the changes from C


History stays intact ‚úîÔ∏è

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üîç Visualizing Revert vs Reset
Original history:
A --- B --- C --- D   (main)

You realize C introduced a bug‚Ä¶
git reset --hard B:

A --- B   (main rewound ‚Äî commits C and D are gone!) ‚ö†Ô∏è


History is rewritten üö®

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß† When to Use Which?








Situation
Use revert
Use reset




You‚Äôre on main or working with others
‚úÖ Yes
‚ùå No


You need to undo a public commit
‚úÖ Yes
‚ùå No


You‚Äôre cleaning up your own history
‚ùå No
‚úÖ Yes


You want to fix a commit but keep edits
‚ùå No
‚úÖ (soft/mixed)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üí° Pro Tips

Always check git log before undoing!
Use reset only on branches you haven‚Äôt shared
Use revert when you need a safe undo that keeps history

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Week 6 Lesson






Recap



Learn about git rebase
Learn about git fetch and git merge
Learn about staging and unstaging files
Learn how to undo some changes

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Mistakes happen ‚Äî that‚Äôs why Git gives us powerful tools to undo changes. In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn two of the most useful commands for fixing things:

git revert: Undo a commit by creating a new commit that cancels it out
git reset: Move your branch pointer to a previous commit (‚ö†Ô∏è this can rewrite history!)





The difference between revert and reset
How to safely undo changes
When to use which command






Go to https://github.com and log in

Click + ‚Üí New repository

Name it something like git-undo-demo

‚úÖ Check Add a README file

Click Create repository

Click the green Code button ‚Üí Select SSH ‚Üí Copy the URL




Open your terminal and run:
git clone git@github.com:your-username/git-undo-demo.git
cd git-undo-demo




We‚Äôll simulate a few commits by editing the README.md file.

Open README.md in RStudio or your preferred text editor

Add a line at the bottom like:

Line 1: Initial test message

Save the file, then run:

git add README.md
git commit -m "Add line 1"

Repeat the process three more times, adding different lines like:

Line 2: More changes
Line 3: Experimental note
Line 4: Oops! Maybe not needed
Each time, save the file, then:
git add README.md
git commit -m "Add line X"
‚úÖ You should now have 4 commits, each adding a line to README.md.
Check your commit history:
git log --oneline





Let‚Äôs say you want to undo the ‚ÄúAdd line 3‚Äù commit ‚Äî but without changing the history.

Find the commit hash:

git log --oneline
Copy the hash for ‚ÄúAdd line 3‚Äù, then:
git revert <hash>
Git will create a new commit that undoes the changes from that commit.
‚úÖ This is a safe way to undo changes ‚Äî especially useful on shared branches like main.




Now let‚Äôs try using reset to go back in time.



reset actually moves your branch pointer and can remove commits ‚Äî so it‚Äôs best used on branches that only you are working on (like feature branches).




This keeps your changes, but undoes the last commit:
git reset --soft HEAD~1
You can now edit or recommit with a new message.




This keeps the file changes but unstages them:
git reset HEAD~1
Run git status to see your changes ‚Äî they‚Äôre back in the working directory.




This discards the last commit and any changes:
git reset --hard HEAD~1
‚úÖ Your repo is now rolled back one commit ‚Äî as if it never happened.













Command
Does What?
Safe for Shared Branches?




git revert
Creates a new commit to undo a change
‚úÖ Yes


git reset --soft
Moves HEAD, keeps changes staged
‚ö†Ô∏è Not recommended


git reset
Moves HEAD, keeps changes unstaged
‚ö†Ô∏è Not recommended


git reset --hard
DANGEROUS: Deletes changes + commits
‚ùå Never on shared branches

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üõ†Ô∏è Goal
Learn how to: - Save changes using git stash - Switch branches safely - Reapply your stashed work

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
üß™ Step-by-Step Instructions

Make sure you‚Äôre inside a Git-tracked project (any project will do).
Open a file and make some changes ‚Äî but don‚Äôt commit yet.
Check your Git status:

git status
You should see the file listed as modified.


üì¶ 1. Stash Your Changes
Run:
git stash
‚úÖ This saves your changes and returns your working directory to a clean state.



üîÑ 2. Switch Branches (or Pull)
Now try switching to another branch:
git checkout main
Or do a pull:
git pull
‚úÖ Your working directory stays clean ‚Äî no conflicts!



‚ôªÔ∏è 3. Reapply the Stash
When you‚Äôre ready to bring back your changes:
git stash apply
‚úÖ Your edits will be restored to the files you changed.



üóëÔ∏è 4. (Optional) Clear the Stash
After applying, you can remove the stash:
git stash drop
Or, to both apply and drop in one step:
git stash pop

üéâ You‚Äôve learned how to pause your work safely and come back to it later!

text:
Commits, hash values and SHA numbers
git log allows us to go back into our project history and see all the commits done in a repo. We can also see the commits of other contributors, we can browse the history to find out past issues or problems.
commit 8cfaee1e447d8e83d745b51ffcd310465afb76b1
Author: Patricia Menendez <patricia.menendez@monash.edu>
Date:   Sat Apr 4 15:49:54 2023 +1000

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Commits, hash values and SHA numbers
text:
Commits, hash values and SHA numbers
The Hash or SHA-1 value (often called refs) is created when we generate a commit. They are a 40 character string stored in hexadecimal. They are effectively unique identifiers for a commit.
There are so many different hashes that you can get away with just using the first few to identify your SHA.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Inspect the SHA numbers
Using your terminal you can inspect your commits and SHA numbers by typing git log in your command line interface:






Tip



To exit the screen press q
To go up in the history, press u
To go down in the history, press d or space.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Inspect the SHA numbers
You can also inspect them from GitHub

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git log

git log is the Git command that allow us to explore the commits history in a Git repository.
git log lists the commits made in that repository in reverse chronological order. That is, the most recent commits show up first.
git log has a great variety of options that allow us to explore commits depending on our preference.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git log
git log --oneline condenses each commit to a single line
3a5bc86 W3 cli updates
4d1b022 W3 shell update

git log -n 3: show last 3 commits
git log --since=01-01-2020: Show commits since‚Ä¶
git log --until=01-01-2020: Show commits until‚Ä¶
git log --author="Michael Lydeamore": Show commits by a single author.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git log and git show

git log -p: shows the difference in each commit. You can chain flags, so git log -p -n 2 will limit to the most recent 2 commits
git log index.qmd will show you all commits on a particular file
git log --oneline -p index.qmd: Shows you all the changes done in the different commits to this file, and their changes
git show will show various information about the repo.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: More options associated with git log
text:
More options associated with git log

git log --stat to see some (abbreivated) stats, like which files were modified, how many files, and how many lines were added or removed
git log --pretty=oneline prints each commit on one line
git log --pretty=format: "%h -%an : %s": Display each commit in one line and display how long ago it was
git log --pretty=format:"%h %s" --graph: Will also show the tree

For more info on git log, please look here.
Remember that if you want to visualize the tree of the repository: VSCode is a great tool for that.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git log and git diff
git log displays revisions, and git diff displays the difference between two revisions in the repo.
It also shows snippets of the text around the part of the file that has changed so you know in which part of the file the changes are happening.
git diff --color-words will display words that have changed in a different color.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Changes within the files in the staging area
text:
Changes within the files in the staging area
git diff --staged

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
git diff options

git diff commit1 commit2: Compare changes between any two commits
git diff branch1 branch2: Compare across branches (!)



git diff master newbranch ./index.qmd: Compare the file index.qmd, between the master and newbranch.




git diff HEAD~2 HEAD --name-only: Shows the files that have changed between the latest commit and the two before that.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Visiting past commits

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Let‚Äôs explore a given commit
In order to look at the status of the files in a given commit, we can use git checkout SHA for example:
git checkout 47ef21k
Once you run this command you will get the
‚ÄúYou are in a detached HEAD state‚Äù
Note: You get to the detached HEAD state by checking a commit directly. Remember the HEAD is a pointer that keeps track of your location within the Git repo.
If we want to see all the commits here we need to use git log --oneline --all.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Detached HEAD repo view

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Detached HEAD
Detached HEAD state gives you the power to check out any commit and explore the older state of a repository without having to create a local branch. In addition, it also allows you to change the repository.






Warning


Any commits made in a detached HEAD state will be lost when you check out any branch.










Solution


Create a branch to keep your commits





If you want to leave the detached HEAD and return to another branch you can simply use git checkout branchname

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Go back into the repository

git checkout 8cfaee1e447d8e8

You are in ‚Äòdetached HEAD‚Äô state (the changes made in this state do not belong to any branch!). That allows you to explore the files that are at that particular location of the repo history.






Tip


No-one wants to be a detached HEAD state. Even git repos.




If you want to bring some files from the past history to your current head, it is best to do this on a new branch

git branch new_branch
git checkout new_branch
or git checkout -b new_branch

Continue working on this branch, then merge

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text: Detached HEAD repo view

text: Git environment tree

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Stage and unstage files
Before you push changes into the remote repo:

git reset filename: Unstage a single file
git reset: Unstage all staged files


For example:

git add filename
git status: filename is added to the staging area
git reset filename: filename will be removed from the staging area.

Intuition: You can think of git reset as the opposite of git add.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Commits

Commits need to be clear and concise.
Commits need to be meaningful so that someone else can understand what you changed in a commit.
Commit early, commit often, but commit meaningfully


Updating file 1: ‚ùå Not meaningful!
Adding gmax for computing maximum value: ‚úÖ

Please watch this video minute 3:16 and consider this when creating your commits! video

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Edit/Amend most recent commit (using cli)
This only works for your most recent commit if it has not been pushed to the remote repo!

Maybe you forgot to add a file or you commit the wrong file. Then you can amend your last commit. That also includes the commit message (if you need to change it).
You can amend the commit directly using the command line interface/console
If you need to add a new file then you can use git add file and then use:

git commit --amend -m "your updated commit message"

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Amending commits
Amending a commit that you‚Äôve already pushed to a remote repo is BAD practice and should be avoided

Amending commits which are already pushed to a remote are more difficult to apply and would require a force push for the rewrite.
Also it will require rebase.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Reverting commits that have been pushed to a remote repo
text:
Reverting commits that have been pushed to a remote repo
git revert: The git revert command can be considered an ‚Äòundo‚Äô type command, however, it is not a traditional undo operation.
Instead of removing the commit from the project history, it figures out how to invert the changes introduced by the commit and appends a new commit with the resulting inverse content. This prevents Git from losing history, which is important for the integrity of your revision history and for reliable collaboration.
You can think of it as a ‚Äúrollback‚Äù: it points your local environment back to a previous commit. Your ‚Äúlocal environment,‚Äù refers to your local repository, staging area, and working directory.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: git revert: When commits have been pushed
text:
git revert: When commits have been pushed

This can be useful, if you need to fix a bug in your code that was introduced by a single commit.
It will record a new commit with the changes introduced by reverting the last commit. If you don‚Äôt want to include the commits reverted then you could use git revert --no-commit.
To revert the previous commit git revert HEAD

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: git revert: When commits have been pushed
text:
git revert: When commits have been pushed

Note that here we are not using HEAD~1 as with reset.The reason is that when using the git reset command we are setting a new HEAD position while with git revert we are actually reverting the commit specified.
Then you will have to commit the changes again for the files to be reverted and for the commit to be undone.
When using the git revert command, Git will automatically open your text editor (VS code) in order to commit the changes.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Removing files

If the files are untracked you can just remove them
If the files are tracked. You can use git to remove the files

git rm file.txt
git status (file already added into the staging area)
git commit -m ‚ÄúDelete file.txt‚Äù
git push origin master

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Mirroring a repository
Mirroring is to replicate the state of a remote or upstream repository in our local machine. By state, we mean all the branches and all the tags as well.
--mirror: 
  Set up a mirror of the source repository. This implies --bare. Compared to --bare,
    --mirror not only maps local branches of the source to local branches of the target,
    it maps all refs (including remote-tracking branches, notes etc.) and sets up a
    refspec configuration such that all these refs are overwritten by a git remote
    update in the target repository.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Example of git mirror

mkdir Example (Don‚Äôt forget to create a folder)
cd Example (And navigate into that folder before the next steps!)
git clone --mirror https://github.com/ETC5513/GitKraken-example.git .git
git config --unset core.bare
git reset --hard

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
By the end of this workshop, you‚Äôll be able to:

Undo commits safely (revert, reset)
Work with old commits using detached HEAD
Recover lost commits using reflog
Modify your last commit with --amend
Clean up tracked and untracked files (git rm, git clean)

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step 1: Make Three Commits
Add one line at a time and commit after each:
Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
You should now have 3 commits. Check with:
git log --oneline

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Step 2: Revert the Most Recent Commit
text:
Step 2: Revert the Most Recent Commit
Let‚Äôs safely undo the last thing you committed ‚Äî no risk of conflicts here.
Run:
git log --oneline
The most recent commit should be the one that added Line 3.
Now run:
git revert HEAD
‚úÖ Git will create a new commit that undoes the last one (removing Line 3).
Check your file and run:
git log --oneline
You should see a new commit at the top with a message like:
Revert "Add line 3"
That‚Äôs how you safely undo a recent commit using revert.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step 3: Reset the Last Commit
Run:
git reset --soft HEAD~1
Now run:
git status
What do you see? Try committing again if you want.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step 1: Checkout an Old Commit
From your log, copy the hash for the first commit.
git checkout <commit-hash>
You‚Äôre now in a detached HEAD state.
Try editing model.R and committing:
git add model.R
git commit -m "Edit in detached HEAD"

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Step 2: Create a Branch to Save Your Work
text:
Step 2: Create a Branch to Save Your Work
git switch -c experiment
You‚Äôre now safe! Run git log and note the history.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Step 1: Make and Reset a Commit
text:
Step 1: Make and Reset a Commit

Make a quick commit (e.g., change notes.txt)
Run:

git reset --hard HEAD~1
The commit is now gone‚Ä¶ or is it?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step 2: Use reflog
git reflog
Find the lost commit hash and restore it:
git checkout <hash>
git switch -c recovered-work
‚úÖ Your work is back!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Step 1: Track and Remove a File
text:
Step 1: Track and Remove a File

Create a file (e.g., temp.txt)
Add and commit it
Now remove it using:

git rm temp.txt
git commit -m "Remove temp file"
Check git log ‚Äî what happened?

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Step 2: Remove a File but Keep It Locally
text:
Step 2: Remove a File but Keep It Locally

Create and commit another file (e.g., data.csv)
Run:

git rm --cached data.csv
git commit -m "Stop tracking data"

The file still exists in your project, but is no longer tracked.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step 3: Clean Untracked Files

Create a few files but don‚Äôt add them to Git.
Preview what would be deleted:

git clean -n

If you‚Äôre sure:

git clean -f
‚úÖ These files are now gone ‚Äî permanently.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Git LFS

Create a repository in GitHub called etc5513-tutorial8-xx where xx is your initials. In that repository, make sure that it has a license, a .gitignore file and a README.md file.
Clone the repository to your local machine
Take the large zip file from moodle
Stage, commit and try to push this file.
What do you notice about the error?
Reset your previous commit.
Add this file using the git lfs workflow. Remember the quotes, and that your file extension is .zip.

git lfs install
git lfs track "*.zip"
git add .gitattributes
git add .
git commit -m "Adding large file"
git push origin main

Push the changes onto GitHub using an extended commit message.

git commit (without the -m flag) will open a text editor for you to type your extended commit.
Add a git annotated tag to the most recent commit called v1.0.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Collaborating with others
With at least one other person, swap repository details. They do not need to add you as a collaborator at this stage.
Clone their repository to your computer.
Practice the following:

Open a pull request with an identified issue with the report. This doesn‚Äôt have to be a real issue, it‚Äôs just for practicing our issues and commit messages.
Your partner should fix the issue, and close the issue using a commit message.
Practice the git fetch workflow, to update your local database without moving HEAD. Then, move your repository HEAD to the latest commit.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Adding version control onto an existing project
text:
Adding version control onto an existing project
Suppose you have a folder on your computer which is not version controlled, and you decide that you would like to start tracking it.
You go to GitHub and create a repo over there. You now have two options:



Approach 1:

Create a GitHub repo
Clone the repo locally
Move all the files and folders from your existing project into this folder
Stage, commit, push




Approach 2:

Open a terminal in the directory for your folder
git init to create a git repostiroy
Stage, commit
git remote add origin git@github.com:...
git push -u origin main

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
section: Adding version control onto an existing project
text:
Adding version control onto an existing project
Option 2 is preferred because it reduces duplication.
GitHub even gives you instructions:


The -u flag says to link remote origin to branch main. it is a one time operation.


Remember you can verify your remotes using git remote -v

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Licensing
Public repos in GitHub make your work publicly available and therefore it is important to establish how your work should be acknowledged if someone else wants to use it.

Public repositories on GitHub are often used to share open source software. For your repository to be truly open source, you‚Äôll need to license it sot that others are free to use, change and distribute the software.

More info here

Location of your license
You can add a license by:

Selecting the option on GitHub when you first create a repo
Later by placing your license text in a file named LICENSE.md


Licenses go in the root of the directory. Some information about licenses is sometimes included in README.md as well, but this is not required.
More info here

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
What is git blame?

A command that shows who last modified each line of a file.
It includes:

Commit hash
Author name
Timestamp
Line content


git blame my_script.R

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Why is git blame useful?

Debugging: Find out who introduced a specific line (or bug).
History: Understand the evolution of code.
Collaboration: Ask helpful questions, not blame people!


It‚Äôs about understanding, not accusing!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Example Output
3f23c8d2 (Alice Smith  2024-03-01 12:03:45 +0000  1) x <- 1
ed32fa01 (Bob Jones    2024-03-02 09:15:23 +0000  2) y <- x + 1
af9345dd (Charlie Liu  2024-03-03 16:42:07 +0000  3) print(y)

Shows who added each line and when.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
How to Investigate Further

Use git show <commit> to see the full commit diff
Or git log -L to follow changes to a specific function or range

git log -L :my_function:my_script.R

Combine with git bisect for deeper history analysis

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
What is git bisect?

A binary search through your commit history to find the commit that introduced a bug.
You tell Git:

A bad commit (where the bug exists)
A good commit (before the bug existed)

Git checks out commits in between until it finds the culprit.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Why use git bisect?

Efficient ‚Äî checks only log‚ÇÇ(n) commits

Ideal for long histories or subtle bugs

You can even automate the check with a script!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Visual Explanation
o---o---o---o---o---o---o
G       ?       ?     B

G: Good commit (known to be bug-free)
B: Bad commit (where bug is present)
Git tests midpoints (?) and narrows down.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Step-by-Step Example
git bisect start
git bisect bad                # current commit is buggy
git bisect good <commit-id>  # known good commit
Git now checks out a middle commit. At each step, you say:
git bisect good   # if no bug
git bisect bad    # if bug is present

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Once Found
Git will show something like:
3f9a2d1a is the first bad commit
Author: Charlie <charlie@example.com>
Then, clean up with:
git bisect reset

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Optional: Automate Testing
git bisect run Rscript test.R
Where test.R returns:

0 ‚Üí good
1 ‚Üí bad

This can save time for large projects!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Slide Structure
To create slides, use horizontal rules (---) to separate them:
## Slide Title

Content for this slide

---

## Another Slide

More content

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Types of Slides
Use different heading levels to create nested slides (vertical stacks):
## Top-level slide

---

### Sub-slide (stacked under the previous)
Useful for going deeper on a topic without changing the horizontal flow.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Fragments (Step-by-step Reveals)
Use ::: blocks with .fragment to reveal content piece-by-piece:
- Item 1
::: {.fragment}
- Item 2 (appears next)
:::
::: {.fragment}
- Item 3 (appears after that)
:::
Press space to reveal each in order during the presentation.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Incremental Reveals
You can automatically reveal bullet points one at a time
by setting incremental: true in your YAML header:
format:
  revealjs:
    incremental: true
Then, write a normal list:
- First point
- Second point
- Third point
Each list item will appear step-by-step when you present.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Columns
Use a .columns div and .column blocks inside:
::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
Left side content
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
Right side content
:::
:::
Useful for comparisons, images + text, or two-part layouts.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Themes & Transitions
You can customize the look:
format:
  revealjs:
    theme: solarized
    transition: fade
Themes include: simple, solarized, beige, night, white, moon, etc.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Speaker Notes
Add presenter notes with ??? under the slide:
## Slide Title

Visible content

???

Notes only the presenter can see.
Press ‚Äòs‚Äô during the presentation to open speaker view.

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
The .smaller class
You can use .smaller to shrink text size for dense slides or long code blocks.

## A slide with smaller text {.smaller}

This slide has .smaller applied!

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Other Features

Use .pull-left / .pull-right to align content
Embed code chunks just like in other .qmd documents
Reveal.js supports:

Math (via LaTeX)
Syntax highlighting
Embedded videos/images

title: ETC5513: Collaborative and Reproducible Practices
text:
Get Started
To render your presentation:

Save your file as slides.qmd
Use the Render button in RStudio
Or run in the terminal:

quarto render slides.qmd
It will output an HTML presentation. Open it in your browser.
